title: Dancing On Ice: Trisha Goddard breaks down claiming she's 'homeless'
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Dancing On Ice’s Trisha Goddard broke down on social media after claiming she’s ‘homeless’ and ‘feeling low’.

The former TV host, who is taking part in the next series of Dancing On Ice, shared a video to Instagram where she said she had to find ‘last-minute’ accommodation and ended up with a ‘mattress from hell’.

She explained to her fans that she should be looking forward to meeting her dance partner, but instead she admitted she was feeling ‘low’ and was in agony due to her back pain.

The post read: ‘Apologies!!! This post should be about being excited to meet my Dancing On Ice pro later today, but Ugh my back! Agony.

‘I’m feeling really low to think of the dramas I’ve been through to finally find (last-minute) accommodation and end up with a bed with a mattress from hell for the next freakin’ six weeks training in the UK.’

The post continued: ‘Watch out! You book and pay for accommodation on a website, only to discover that the place advertised as being available for the dates you need, actually isn’t! Cue nightmare scenarios of wrangling refunds and trying to find somewhere else.’

Aw poor Trisha (Picture: Instagram/@therealtrishagoddard)

The video also showed a rather tired-looking Trisha rubbing her eyes, and as she yawned she told her followers: ‘I can hardly walk due to backache.’

The full line-up for the 2020 series has been confirmed and it includes Love Island’s Maura Higgins, Michael Barrymore, and footballer Kevin Kilbane.

ITV newsreader Lucrezia Millarini was the fourth confirmed contestant, followed by Ian ‘H’ Watkins from Steps, and Coronation Street actress Lucy George.

Other names include model Caprice, Joe Swash, Diversity’s Perri Kiely, Libby Clegg and magician Ben Hanlan.

Next year’s series is the first without judge Jason Gardiner, who quit the show earlier this year and will be replaced by John Barrowman.

Ashley Banjo will remain on the judging panel alongside Jayne Torvill and Christopher Dean.

Dancing On Ice kicks off in January 2020 on ITV.
